awd_titl_txt: Edge Coloring and Edge Cover Packing
awd_abstract_narration:
Graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects. A graph is made up of vertices which are connected by edges. Graph edge-coloring is a well-established subject in the field of graph theory. It is a basic combinatorial optimization problem:  color the edges of a graph with as few colors as possible such that each edge receives a color and adjacent edges, that is, different edges incident to a common vertex, receive different colors. It has a rich theory, abundant applications, and many beautiful conjectures.  It is studied not only by mathematicians but also by computer scientists. In this project, the PI will develop new re-coloring techniques to attack fundamental conjectures in the field. The project will, at the same time, train graduate students and disseminate results to researchers in the area.

The main topic of this project concerns extensions and variations of the method of Tashkinov trees, which is the most powerful and sophisticated technique for multigraph edge-coloring developed so far.  Previously, almost all edge-coloring techniques were based on Vizing's adjacency lemmas, which have certain limitations.  The Tashkinov tree method generalizes the earlier methods of Vizing fans and Kierstead paths for multigraphs.  Developments around Tashkinov trees have opened new avenues in the study of graph edge-coloring and led to a number of significant new results such as the proof of the well-known Goldberg-Seymour Conjecture.  The investigator is currently developing stronger versions of Tashkinov tree type results for simple graphs, which will lead to substantial progress toward some longstanding conjectures in this field.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on advancing the understanding of the edge coloring problem (ECP), a fundamental challenge in graph theory that involves partitioning the edge set of a graph into independent sets called matchings. Specifically, the chromatic index, which represents the minimum number of such sets, has wide-ranging implications for discrete mathematics, combinatorial optimization, and theoretical computer science.

 The ECP is known to be NP-hard, making the determination of the chromatic index for general graphs an exceptionally difficult problem. However, the PI and collaborators made significant theoretical contributions by proving that the chromatic index lies between two consecutive integers, a value that can be computed in polynomial time. Their research further delves into the structural properties of graphs whose chromatic index differs from its two most obvious lower bounds. These findings shed light on unresolved questions in graph theory and provide new avenues for exploring the chromatic index in both theoretical and practical contexts.

 The project has yielded significant publications in top-tier journals and led to several presentations at both international and national conferences. Additionally, the research has inspired novel algorithmic approaches and techniques that could potentially apply to broader combinatorial optimization problems.

 The project had a significant educational and mentoring component. The PI played an active role in mentoring Ph.D. students, helping them engage in cutting-edge research in graph theory, and guiding them through the complex mathematical landscape of edge coloring problems. This included fostering junior mathematicians' development through direct mentorship and contributing to their professional growth in a supportive academic environment.

  Furthermore, the results of this research extend beyond theoretical developments. ECP, due to its wide applicability, is relevant in various real-world domains, including network scheduling, resource allocation, and even coding theory. The dissemination of the research outcomes in reputable journals and conferences helped to enhance the visibility of these findings and spurred further investigation into edge coloring's broader applications.

Through this project, not only were advances made in the specific field of graph theory, but it also fostered an academic environment where junior researchers could develop crucial skills, both in mathematical research and professional networking, contributing to the growth of the academic community in discrete mathematics.
